elements.content: Four homoleptic coordination polymers of general composition [Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­X (4ABN ≡ 4-aminobenzonitrile) were synthesized and characterized by X-ray single crystal structure analysis. For X = NO3 – (P21/n, Z = 4; 1), PF6 – (P21/n, Z = 4; 2), and ClO4 – (P21/n, Z = 4; 3), similar topologies with undulated layers (63 nets) are found, which are separated by the anions. For X = SO3CF3 – (P1̅, Z = 2; 4), a one-dimensional structural fragment with polymeric double-bridged cationic chains again separated by the anions is formed. It is rationalized that different dimensionalities of the polymeric structural fragments depend upon the size of the separating counteranions. This simple rule can also be applied for already known ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4.

For X = NO3 - (P21/n, Z = 4; 1), PF6 - (P21/n, Z = 4; 2), and ClO4 - (P21/n, Z = 4; 3), similar topologies with undulated layers (63 nets) are found, which are separated by the anions. For X = SO3CF3 - (P1̅, Z = 2; 4), a one-dimensional structural fragment with polymeric double-bridged cationic chains again separated by the anions is formed. It is rationalized that different dimensionalities of the polymeric structural fragments depend upon the size of the separating counteranions. This simple rule can also be applied for already known ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4.

elements.content: In four homoleptic coordination polymers of general composition [Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­X (4ABN ≡ 4-aminobenzonitrile), polymeric cations ∞ n {[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+} are found, which are connected by the respective anions (X = NO3 −, ClO4 −, PF6 −, SO3CF3 −). Depending on the size of the anion, different dimensionalities of the cations are found: one-dimensional chains for larger SO3CF3 − and two-dimensional layers for the smaller anions.

Depending on the size of the anion, different dimensionalities of the cations are found: one-dimensional chains for larger SO3CF3 - and two-dimensional layers for the smaller anions.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) and especially their porous congeners, frequently named MOFs (metal-organic frameworks) or PCPs (porous coordination polymers), are in the focus of many research groups worldwide. For MOFs/PCPs many promising applications are discussed, but also nonporous CPs show interesting properties. Another intriguing aspect of CPs is their easy synthetic availability along with the promise to assemble new compounds from simple starting materials. In principle, this (self-)­assembly should allow the directed synthesis of new CPs with a topology determined by the structural properties of the starting compounds. This research field, frequently called crystal engineering, was first introduced by G. M. J. Schmidt in 1971 and was described as “systematic work on the forces controlling molecular packing arrangement”. Many factors affect the self-assembly of CPs. The most important factors are preferred coordination geometry of the metal cation, denticity and geometry of the organic linker molecule, temperature and pressure during synthesis, presence of solvent molecules, metal to ligand ratio, and intermolecular interactions such as van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds. Today, it is possible to predict trends of self-assembly, but, in most cases, not to give accurate predictions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) and especially their porous congeners, frequently named MOFs (metal-organic frameworks) or PCPs (porous coordination polymers), are in the focus of many research groups worldwide. For MOFs/PCPs many promising applications are discussed, but also nonporous CPs show interesting properties. Another intriguing aspect of CPs is their easy synthetic availability along with the promise to assemble new compounds from simple starting materials. In principle, this (self-)assembly should allow the directed synthesis of new CPs with a topology determined by the structural properties of the starting compounds. This research field, frequently called crystal engineering, was first introduced by G. M. J. Schmidt in 1971 and was described as "systematic work on the forces controlling molecular packing arrangement". Many factors affect the self-assembly of CPs. The most important factors are preferred coordination geometry of the metal cation, denticity and geometry of the organic linker molecule, temperature and pressure during synthesis, presence of solvent molecules, metal to ligand ratio, and intermolecular interactions such as van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds. Today, it is possible to predict trends of self-assembly, but, in most cases, not to give accurate predictions.

elements.content: One of our research projects is the synthesis of CPs with simple linear ligands. Here we have chosen neutral 4-aminobenzonitrile (4ABN) to eliminate ionic influences of the ligand. In addition, 4ABN is a push–pull ligand with two different coordinating groups, which, in case of acentric CPs, should lead to interesting optical properties, for example, strong second-harmonic generation (SHG). Up to now, only a few CPs with 4ABN as the linking ligand are described. Recently, we were able to synthesize and structurally characterize the first homoleptic CP of 4ABN, namely, ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4. Polymeric cationic layers are formed, which are separated by BF4 – counteranions. To investigate the influence of counteranions on the topology of these CPs, we have synthesized four new homoleptic CPs with 4-aminobenzonitrile as the linking ligand and Ag+ as the node. The resulting compounds ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­NO3 (1), ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­PF6 (2), ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­ClO4 (3), ∞ 1[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­SO3CF3 (4), and known ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4 (5) allowed us to investigate the influence of counteranions on the self-assembly of CPs of 4ABN.

Recently, we were able to synthesize and structurally characterize the first homoleptic CP of 4ABN, namely, ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4. Polymeric cationic layers are formed, which are separated by BF4 - counteranions. To investigate the influence of counteranions on the topology of these CPs, we have synthesized four new homoleptic CPs with 4-aminobenzonitrile as the linking ligand and Ag+ as the node. The resulting compounds ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]NO3 (1), ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]PF6 (2), ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]ClO4 (3), ∞ 1[Ag(4ABN)4/2]SO3CF3 (4), and known ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4 (5) allowed us to investigate the influence of counteranions on the self-assembly of CPs of 4ABN.

elements.content: Compound 1 was first mentioned by Ahuja et al. in 1990. Their investigation was based on analytical data, molar conductance, and infrared spectra. They predicted a monodentately coordinating ligand 4ABN (via the amino group) and a terminally bonded monodentate NO3 – ligand. Accordingly, the cyano group is noncoordinating. After determining the crystal structure of 1 by X-ray single crystal diffraction data, we now present a different structural picture, which is in contradiction to ref . ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­NO3 (1) crystallizes in centrosymmetric space group P21/n (No. 14) with four formula units per unit cell. Each Ag+ is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of the 4ABN ligand in a distorted tetrahedral geometry: twice by cyano groups and twice by amino groups. The mean Ag–N distances between Ag+ and Ncyano are shorter than those between Ag+ and Namino. They range from 2.204(3) Å (Ag1–N4) and 2.317(4) Å (Ag1–N2) for Ag–Ncyano to 2.330(3) Å (Ag1–N3) and 2.432(4) Å (Ag1–N1) for Ag–Namino. The N–Ag–N angles within the AgN4 tetrahedron deviate significantly from the ideal geometry. They range from 93.7(1)° (N4–Ag1–N1) to 125.8(2)° (N4–Ag1–N2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compound 1 was first mentioned by Ahuja et al. in 1990. Their investigation was based on analytical data, molar conductance, and infrared spectra. They predicted a monodentately coordinating ligand 4ABN (via the amino group) and a terminally bonded monodentate NO3 - ligand. Accordingly, the cyano group is noncoordinating. After determining the crystal structure of 1 by X-ray single crystal diffraction data, we now present a different structural picture, which is in contradiction to ref . ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]NO3 (1) crystallizes in centrosymmetric space group P21/n (No. 14) with four formula units per unit cell. Each Ag+ is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of the 4ABN ligand in a distorted tetrahedral geometry: twice by cyano groups and twice by amino groups. The mean Ag-N distances between Ag+ and Ncyano are shorter than those between Ag+ and Namino. They range from 2.204(3) Å (Ag1-N4) and 2.317(4) Å (Ag1-N2) for Ag-Ncyano to 2.330(3) Å (Ag1-N3) and 2.432(4) Å (Ag1-N1) for Ag-Namino. The N-Ag-N angles within the AgN4 tetrahedron deviate significantly from the ideal geometry. They range from 93.7(1)° (N4-Ag1-N1) to 125.8(2)° (N4-Ag1-N2).

elements.content: Ag+ and the ligand form a two-dimensional (2D), homoleptic CP; the NO3 – anion is not coordinating to Ag+. Because of that, it is highly mobile, as can be seen from the large ellipsoids in the ORTEP plot shown in Figure . The only interactions of the anion with the cation are hydrogen bonds between hydrogen atoms of the amino group and oxygen atoms of the nitrate anion (Figure ). The distances of the O···H bonds range from 2.226 Å (O3···H3A) to 2.512 Å (O2···H1B). So they can be classified as weak. As frequently observed for NO3 –, it acts as a bidentately bridging ligand (4-connector). O3 forms hydrogen bonds to H3A and H3B of amino groups of different ligands. O1 is connected to H1A of an amino group of a third ligand. All these hydrogen bonds are within one cationic layer. Two layers are connected by hydrogen bonds between O2 and H1B of another amino group.

elements.content:
The polymeric cation ∞ 2{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+} consists of AgN4 tetrahedra connected by 4ABN forming undulated layers. The stacking of these honeycomb-like layers (63 nets) is shown in Figure .

The connectivity within a layer is shown in Figure . Each Ag+ is connected to four ligands, twice via an amino group and twice via a cyano group. The ligand connects two different Ag+ cations. Most frequently a 3D diamond-like network is found for a 4-connector node and a 2-connector ligand. But here layers are formed: each Ag+ is connected to only three different Ag+ nodes, as two nodes are linked by two 4ABN ligands. These ligands are aligned antiparallel to each other, meaning that the aromatic rings are parallel to each other, but the functional groups are switched (Figure ). The atomic distances within the linker ligand are, as expected, the same as within the free ligand. Only the C–N bond lengths differ to the free ligand. While the CN bond is comparable to noncoordinating 4ABN (free 4ABN: 1.143(5) Å), the C–N bond of the amino group is longer than in the free ligand (free 4ABN: 1.360(5) Å). In 1 the bond lengths range from 1.135(5) Å (C7–N2) to 1.140(5) Å (C14–N4) for C–Ncyano and from 1.402(5) Å (C1–N1) to 1.406(5) Å (C8–N3) for C–Namino. For noncoordinating 4ABN, the frequency of the CN stretching vibration is found at 2213 cm–1 (IR spectrum of 4ABN measured as KBr pellet). Because of the coordination of the cyano group to Ag+, this band is shifted to 2246 cm–1. As a further consequence of the coordination the band is split, so that there is a second band of the stretching vibration at 2217 cm–1. The latter is assigned to combination bands. Shift and splitting of the CN stretching vibration are observed in the Raman spectrum as well as in the IR spectrum (: Figures S5 and S6). On the other hand, the bands of the symmetric N–H-stretching mode do not show a significant shift.

elements.content: ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­PF6 (2) is also a homoleptic, 2D coordination polymer and crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (No. 14) with four formula units per unit cell. An ORTEP plot is shown in Figure . Each Ag+ is tetrahedrally coordinated by four nitrogen atoms in a distorted way: twice by a cyano group and twice by an amino group. The Ag–N distances range from 2.238(4) Å (Ag1–N2) to 2.302(4) Å (Ag1–N4) for Ncyano and from 2.382(4) Å (Ag1–N1) to 2.449(4) Å (Ag1–N3) for Namino. The N–Ag–N angles range from 94.9(2)° (N2–Ag1–N3) to 125.5(2)° (N2–Ag1–N4). As expected the anion PF6 – is not coordinated to Ag+. Its enlarged thermal ellipsoids (Figure ) point to a high mobility.

elements.content: ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­PF6 crystallizes with the same topology as described for 1. The cationic polymer ∞ 2{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+} also forms undulated layers, which are connected by a complex hydrogen bonding net involving the anion. A sketch of the crystal structure showing the hydrogen bonding net is shown in Figure . The distances of the F···H bonds range from 2.307 Å (F5···H3A) to 2.661 Å (F6···H3B), so they can be classified as weak. The amino hydrogen atoms H1B, H3A, and H3B are involved in these hydrogen bonds, whereas H1A does not form any F···H bonds shorter than 2.7 Å. H1B is coordinated to one fluorine atom (F3), whereas H3A and H3B are coordinated to two fluorine atoms each (F1, F5 and F1, F6, respectively).

elements.content: There are no significant short Ag···Ag distances: 5.7093(9) Å between two layers and 9.6757(9) Å in one layer forming an Ag2(4ABN)2 ring. The CN bond length is 1.129(6) Å (C7–N2) respectively 1.134(6) Å (C14–N4), thus slightly shorter than in the free ligand. However, the C–N bond of the amino group is longer than the respective bond in the uncoordinated ligand: 1.402(6) Å (C8–N3) and 1.411(5) Å (C1–N1). As already observed for 1, the CN stretching band is split into two bands. The blue-shifted band (2240 cm–1) is assigned to the symmetrical stretching vibration (: Figures S7 and S8).

elements.content: ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­ClO4 (3) crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (No. 14) with four formula units per unit cell. It is also a homoleptic, 2D coordination polymer very similar to compounds 1 and 2. 3 contains distorted tetrahedrally coordinated Ag+ cations. The resulting cation ∞ 2{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+} forms undulated layers with Ag–N distances in the range from 2.222(6) Å (Ag1–N4) to 2.322(6) Å (Ag1–N2) for Ncyano, respectively 2.372(5) Å (Ag1–N3) to 2.459(5) Å (Ag1–N1) for Namino. The N–Ag–N angles range from 94.8(2)° (N2–Ag1–N1) to 124.8(2)° (N4–Ag1–N2) exemplifying the distortion of the tetrahedron. As expected, the ClO4 – anion does not coordinate to Ag+, thus exhibiting large thermal ellipsoids as shown in Figure .

elements.content: There are weak H bonds connecting the cationic layers via the perchlorate anion. The O···H bond distances range from 2.387 Å (H3B···O2) to 2.603 Å (H3A···O2). A sketch of the crystal structure showing the connectivity via hydrogen bonds is given in Figure . The perchlorate anion coordinates bidentately to H1B via oxygen atoms O1 and O3. The former is also part of a second bidentate coordination to another amino hydrogen atom (H1A) together with O4. Both hydrogen atoms belong to the same cationic layer. Another hydrogen atom belonging to this layer and being involved in the hydrogen bond network is H3B. It is coordinated to the ClO4 – anion via O2, which also acts as a bridging atom connecting two cationic layers, as O2 further bounds to H3A of another layer.

elements.content: Compared to compounds 1 and 2, a similar trend in the atomic distances is observed: the CN bond length is similar to the distances in free 4ABN: 1.145(8) Å (C7–N2) and 1.146(8) Å (C14–N4), while the C–N single bond of the amino group is longer than in the free ligand: 1.407(7) Å (C8–N3) and 1.417(8) Å (C1–N1). As observed for 1 and 2, there is a shift and splitting of the symmetrical CN stretching vibration in the Raman spectrum (: Figure S9). There are two bands: the first at 2241 cm–1 and the second at 2227 cm–1. The blue shift of the bands is a consequence of the coordination to Ag+. No IR spectrum was measured due to the unpredictable behavior of perchlorate compounds upon application of pressure during the preparation of a KBr pellet.
elements.clean_text: Compared to compounds 1 and 2, a similar trend in the atomic distances is observed: the CN bond length is similar to the distances in free 4ABN: 1.145(8) Å (C7-N2) and 1.146(8) Å (C14-N4), while the C-N single bond of the amino group is longer than in the free ligand: 1.407(7) Å (C8-N3) and 1.417(8) Å (C1-N1). As observed for 1 and 2, there is a shift and splitting of the symmetrical CN stretching vibration in the Raman spectrum (: Figure S9). There are two bands: the first at 2241 cm-1 and the second at 2227 cm-1. The blue shift of the bands is a consequence of the coordination to Ag+. No IR spectrum was measured due to the unpredictable behavior of perchlorate compounds upon application of pressure during the preparation of a KBr pellet.

elements.content:
The shortest Ag···Ag distances are 5.690(1) Å (Ag1···Ag1′, Ag1 and Ag1′ belonging to different layers) and 9.756(2) Å (Ag1···Ag1′, Ag1 and Ag1′ forming an Ag2(4ABN)2 ring within a layer).

∞ 1[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­SO3CF3 (4) crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅ (No. 2) with two formula units per unit cell. An ORTEP plot of the asymmetric unit with a completed coordination sphere of Ag+ is shown in Figure .

elements.content: Each Ag+ is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry by four 4ABN ligands, twice by amino groups and twice by cyano groups. The Ag–N distances range from 2.203(4) Å (Ag1–N4) to 2.233(4) Å (Ag1–N2) for Ncyano and from 2.407(4) Å (Ag1–N1) to 2.540(4) Å (Ag1–N3) for Namino. SO3CF3 – is not coordinating to Ag+. Angles of the AgN4 tetrahedron range from 94.9(2)° (N2–Ag1–N1) to 130.0(2)° (N4–Ag1–N2). The resulting cations, ∞ 1{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+}, form double-bridged chains running along [112], which are connected via the anions by hydrogen bonds (Figure ). These hydrogen bonds have N–H···O distances, which range from 2.095 Å (H1B···O3) to 2.269 Å (H3B···O1). Hence they are weak. The fluorine atoms are not involved in the hydrogen bonding net. So the hydrogen bonds are just formed by oxygen atoms O1 and O3 and hydrogen atoms (Figures and ). The anion connects three cationic chains. Both oxygen atoms are connected to two hydrogen atoms of two different chains. Consequently, one chain is bonded twice (Figure ).

So the hydrogen bonds are just formed by oxygen atoms O1 and O3 and hydrogen atoms (Figures  and ). The anion connects three cationic chains. Both oxygen atoms are connected to two hydrogen atoms of two different chains. Consequently, one chain is bonded twice (Figure ).

elements.content: As observed for compounds 1–3, the distances within the 4ABN ligand differ slightly to free 4ABN. The CN bond length ranges from 1.139(5) Å (C14–N4) to 1.141(6) Å (C7–N2), whereas the C–N bond lengths of the amino group are 1.402(5) Å (C8–N3) and 1.408(4) Å (C1–N1). Thus, the CN distances are similar to those in free 4ABN, whereas the C–Namino distances are slightly enhanced compared to the free ligand. In contrast to the compounds above here no splitting of the symmetrical CN stretching vibration is observed in the Raman spectrum, but in the IR spectrum (: Figures S10 and S11). Both spectra show a blue shift of the main band to 2244 cm–1 (IR) and 2241 cm–1 (Raman) compared to the free ligand. The combination band is found at 2215 cm–1 (IR). These results are summarized in Table S1 in the .

elements.content: Within a chain each Ag+ is only connected to two different Ag+ cations via 4ABN ligands; that is, two Ag+ cations are always linked by two ligands thus forming Ag2(4ABN)2 rings. This is different for compounds 1–3, where each Ag+ within a layer is connected to three different Ag+ cations via 4ABN. Just as observed for compounds 1–3, there are no notable short Ag···Ag distances in 4: 5.430(1) Å (Ag1···Ag1′, Ag1 and Ag1′ belonging to different chains) respectively 9.665(3) Å (Ag1···Ag1′, Ag1 and Ag1′ forming an Ag2(4ABN)2 ring within a chain).

elements.content: The presented compounds 1–4 and the already introduced compound ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4 14 form a series of homoleptic coordination polymers ∞ n [Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­X. As often observed for Ag+ compounds, a tetrahedral coordination of Ag+ is found. All compounds consist of cationic polymers ∞ n {[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+} (n = 1, 2) and noncoordinating anions X–. They only differ in terms of dimensionality. While compounds with X = BF4, PF6, NO3, and ClO4 form 2D cationic layers ∞ 2{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+}, the compound with X = SO3CF3 forms one-dimensional (1D) chains ∞ 1{[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]+}. It is already obvious from the similar unit cells (see Table ) that 1–3 and ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4 14 have an identical topology (Figure S12 in the ). So in these four compounds the polymeric cations can be considered as being identical. Only the anions, which connect the polymeric layers, are different. However, a completely different topology with polymeric chains is found in 4. It can be speculated that the volume of the anion directs the self-assembly of a 2D or a 1D compound. To rationalize this behavior, we have calculated the respective volumes of the anions from simple, well-known salts. To exclude the influence of the cation on these calculations, we have only chosen potassium compounds. The results of these calculations are presented in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The presented compounds 1-4 and the already introduced compound ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4 14 form a series of homoleptic coordination polymers ∞  n [Ag(4ABN)4/2]X. As often observed for Ag+ compounds, a tetrahedral coordination of Ag+ is found. All compounds consist of cationic polymers ∞  n {[Ag(4ABN)4/2]+} (n = 1, 2) and noncoordinating anions X-. They only differ in terms of dimensionality. While compounds with X = BF4, PF6, NO3, and ClO4 form 2D cationic layers ∞ 2{[Ag(4ABN)4/2]+}, the compound with X = SO3CF3 forms one-dimensional (1D) chains ∞ 1{[Ag(4ABN)4/2]+}. It is already obvious from the similar unit cells (see Table ) that 1-3 and ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4 14 have an identical topology (Figure S12 in the ). So in these four compounds the polymeric cations can be considered as being identical. Only the anions, which connect the polymeric layers, are different. However, a completely different topology with polymeric chains is found in 4. It can be speculated that the volume of the anion directs the self-assembly of a 2D or a 1D compound. To rationalize this behavior, we have calculated the respective volumes of the anions from simple, well-known salts. To exclude the influence of the cation on these calculations, we have only chosen potassium compounds. The results of these calculations are presented in Table .

The smallest volume was calculated for the nitrate anion (V = 53.5 Å3) followed by tetrafluoroborate (V = 56.8 Å3), perchlorate (V = 63.7 Å3), and hexafluorophosphate (V = 88.0 Å3). The triflate anion has the largest volume: V = 116.6 Å3. It is obvious that latter requires the largest space in the process of self-assembling. So, a 2D linking of Ag+ is obviously difficult with respect to packing density. A similar influence of counteranions on the dimensionality of coordination networks formed from Ag+ and linear chain dinitriles has already been observed by others and thus confirms our findings and conclusions. The volumes of the unit cells of 1–4 also follow this trend. The smallest unit cell volume was found for 1 (1593.1 Å3), followed by ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4 (1659.0 Å3), 3 (1691.4 Å3), and 2 (1788.2 Å3). The largest volume was observed for 4 (1875.0 Å3 assuming four formula units per unit cell). By subtracting the volume of the anions from these unit cell volumes, one obtains the following volumes of the polymeric cations per formula unit: 344.8 Å3 (1), 359.1 Å3 (2), 359.2 Å3 (3), 352.2 Å3 (4), and 358.0 Å3 (∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4). Obviously, the more or less spherical anions ClO4 –, PF6 –, and BF4 – lead to very similar volumes of the polymeric cations pointing to a similar packing in the solid state. The smallest volume of the cation is calculated for the CP with trigonal planar NO3 –. The volume of the cation of the CP with SO3CF3 – is somewhere in-between and does therefore not reflect the different topologies of the crystal arrangement. We think that this indicates an “optimized” close-packing in all compounds.

The triflate anion has the largest volume: V = 116.6 Å3. It is obvious that latter requires the largest space in the process of self-assembling. So, a 2D linking of Ag+ is obviously difficult with respect to packing density. A similar influence of counteranions on the dimensionality of coordination networks formed from Ag+ and linear chain dinitriles has already been observed by others and thus confirms our findings and conclusions. The volumes of the unit cells of 1-4 also follow this trend. The smallest unit cell volume was found for 1 (1593.1 Å3), followed by ∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4 (1659.0 Å3), 3 (1691.4 Å3), and 2 (1788.2 Å3). The largest volume was observed for 4 (1875.0 Å3 assuming four formula units per unit cell). By subtracting the volume of the anions from these unit cell volumes, one obtains the following volumes of the polymeric cations per formula unit: 344.8 Å3 (1), 359.1 Å3 (2), 359.2 Å3 (3), 352.2 Å3 (4), and 358.0 Å3 (∞ 2[Ag(4ABN)4/2]BF4). Obviously, the more or less spherical anions ClO4 -, PF6 -, and BF4 - lead to very similar volumes of the polymeric cations pointing to a similar packing in the solid state. The smallest volume of the cation is calculated for the CP with trigonal planar NO3 -. The volume of the cation of the CP with SO3CF3 - is somewhere in-between and does therefore not reflect the different topologies of the crystal arrangement. We think that this indicates an "optimized" close-packing in all compounds.

elements.content: As smaller anions lead to a 2D polymeric cation and larger SO3CF3 – to a 1D cation, it was obvious to investigate compounds with even smaller anions like F– (volume calculated from KF: 12.0 Å3). But all our attempts to synthesize a potential compound ∞ n [Ag­(4ABN)4/2]F failed up to now mainly due to the low solubility of AgF in common solvents.

elements.content: In compounds 1–4 as well as in ∞ 2[Ag­(4ABN)4/2]­BF4, the CN bond lengths of the cyano groups of coordinating 4ABN are similar to that of noncoordinating 4ABN (1.129–1.146 Å vs 1.143 Å in free 4ABN). The frequency of the stretching vibration of the CN group however shows a significant blue shift (Table S1 in the ) of approximately 30 cm–1. This is attributed to the fact that in coordinating 4ABN the cyanoaniline form with a C–N triple bond is dominating, whereas in free 4ABN the influence of the iminoquinone form of 4ABN with a C–N double bond cannot be neglected (for mesomeric forms see Scheme ). In other words, it reflects a larger contribution of the N2s orbital of the donor atom to the CN σ-bonding system upon σ-donation of the lone pair electrons to the CN nitrogen atom. It is worth mentioning that this is only observable in the frequencies of the bands of the C–N groups in the IR and Raman spectra, whereas the C–N distances are almost not influenced within their standard deviations. On the other hand, a significant difference of the distances of the C–N bond of the ···C-NH2 group is found: 1.402–1.417 Å in coordinating 4ABN compared to 1.360 Å in free 4ABN. Again, this reflects the higher importance of the iminoquinone form in free 4ABN, whereas in coordinating 4ABN the cyanoaniline form is dominating. Surprisingly, this effect is not found in the frequencies of the C–N stretching vibrations (Table S1 in the ).

elements.content:
Left: cyanoaniline form, right: iminoquinone form.

Experimental Section

Single Crystals of 1–4 were obtained by isothermal evaporation of ethanolic solutions of 4-aminobenzonitrile (4ABN) and the respective silver salts. The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, the purity was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) and elemental analysis. IR and Raman spectra were recorded with a focus on the C–N­(amino) and CN­(cyano) stretching vibrations. In none of the syntheses given below the yield was optimized, and hence no yield was determined. But all compounds were obtained in larger amounts, and XRPD and elemental analysis confirm their purity. For all syntheses the starting materials were used without further purification.

Experimental Section

Single Crystals of 1-4 were obtained by isothermal evaporation of ethanolic solutions of 4-aminobenzonitrile (4ABN) and the respective silver salts. The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, the purity was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) and elemental analysis. IR and Raman spectra were recorded with a focus on the C-N(amino) and CN(cyano) stretching vibrations. In none of the syntheses given below the yield was optimized, and hence no yield was determined. But all compounds were obtained in larger amounts, and XRPD and elemental analysis confirm their purity. For all syntheses the starting materials were used without further purification.

Safety note!

Perchlorate salts of silver complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive! Only small amounts of materials should be prepared and handled with care.

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">2</sup>[Ag­(4ABN)<sub>4/2</sub>]­NO<sub>3</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

In a beaker 118.1 mg (1 mmol) of 4ABN was dissolved in ethanol (5 mL). A saturated solution of AgNO3 in 10 mL of ethanol was added. The beaker was covered with a perforated foil. For slower crystallization, the beaker was placed in a refrigerator (T: approximately 4 °C). After two weeks, light yellow, transparent crystals of 1 precipitated. The supernatant solution was filtered off and the crystals were washed with small amounts of cold ethanol. A suitable crystal of 1 for structure analysis was isolated. According to XRPD and elemental analysis, the sample is single phase. Elemental analysis for C14H12N5O3Ag1 (406.16): calcd C, 41.40%, H, 2.98%, N, 17.24%; found C, 41.11%, H, 2.99%, N, 16.99%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3479 (w), 3372 (m), 3214 (w), 2246 (w), 2217 (m), 1627 (m), 1602 (m), 1513 (m). Raman (cm–1): 3078 (w), 2246 (m), 2217 (m), 1602 (m).

elements.content: For crystal structure determination, the isolated single crystals were placed in glass capillaries and fixed. The capillaries were mounted on a Stoe IPDS I or Stoe IPDS II single crystal diffractometer (T ≈ 293 K, Mo–Kα radiation). For data collection and reduction, the Stoe program package was applied. Structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92. The structural model was completed using difference Fourier maps calculated with SHELXL-97, which was also used for the final refinements. All programs were run under the WinGX system. A numerical absorption correction was carried out with the programs X-RED and X-SHAPE. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of the 4ABN ligand were calculated and refined “riding” with fixed distances (C–H: 0.93 Å, N–H: 0.90 Å). More details of the crystal structure determinations and refinements are given in Table . Selected atomic distances and angles are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination

For crystal structure determination, the isolated single crystals were placed in glass capillaries and fixed. The capillaries were mounted on a Stoe IPDS I or Stoe IPDS II single crystal diffractometer (T ~ 293 K, Mo-Kα radiation). For data collection and reduction, the Stoe program package was applied. Structures were solved by direct methods using SIR-92. The structural model was completed using difference Fourier maps calculated with SHELXL-97, which was also used for the final refinements. All programs were run under the WinGX system. A numerical absorption correction was carried out with the programs X-RED and X-SHAPE. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of the 4ABN ligand were calculated and refined "riding" with fixed distances (C-H: 0.93 Å, N-H: 0.90 Å). More details of the crystal structure determinations and refinements are given in Table . Selected atomic distances and angles are given in Table .

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">2</sup>[Ag­(4ABN)<sub>4/2</sub>]­NO<sub>3</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

In a beaker 118.1 mg (1 mmol) of 4ABN was dissolved in ethanol (5 mL). A saturated solution of AgNO3 in 10 mL of ethanol was added. The beaker was covered with a perforated foil. For slower crystallization, the beaker was placed in a refrigerator (T: approximately 4 °C). After two weeks, light yellow, transparent crystals of 1 precipitated. The supernatant solution was filtered off and the crystals were washed with small amounts of cold ethanol. A suitable crystal of 1 for structure analysis was isolated. According to XRPD and elemental analysis, the sample is single phase. Elemental analysis for C14H12N5O3Ag1 (406.16): calcd C, 41.40%, H, 2.98%, N, 17.24%; found C, 41.11%, H, 2.99%, N, 16.99%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3479 (w), 3372 (m), 3214 (w), 2246 (w), 2217 (m), 1627 (m), 1602 (m), 1513 (m). Raman (cm–1): 3078 (w), 2246 (m), 2217 (m), 1602 (m).

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">2</sup>[Ag­(4ABN)<sub>4/2</sub>]­PF<sub>6</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

In a beaker 236.2 mg (2 mmol) of 4ABN and 252.8 mg (1 mmol) of AgPF6 were dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. The beaker was covered with a perforated foil. After seven days, light yellow, transparent crystals of 2 precipitated. A suitable crystal for structure analysis was isolated. According to XRPD and elemental analysis, the sample is single-phase. Elemental analysis for C14H12N4P1F6Ag1 (489.12): calcd C, 34.38%, H, 2.47%, N, 11.45%; found C, 34.47%, H, 2.93%, N, 11.67%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3477 (w), 3425 (w), 3419 (w), 3371 (w), 3344 (m), 3212 (w), 2242 (w), 2213 (m), 1627 (m), 1602 (m), 1515 (m). Raman (cm–1): 3068 (w), 2240 (m), 2227 (m), 1602 (m).

<sub arrange="stack">∞</sub> <sup arrange="stack">2</sup>[Ag­(4ABN)<sub>4/2</sub>]­ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

In a beaker 236.2 mg (2 mmol) of 4ABN and 225.3 mg (1 mmol) of AgClO4 were dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. The beaker was covered with a perforated foil. After seven days, the solvent was evaporated and light yellow, transparent crystals of 3 remained. A suitable crystal for structure analysis was isolated. According to XRPD and elemental analysis the sample is single-phase. Elemental analysis for C14H12N4O4Cl1Ag1 (443.60): calcd C, 37.91%, H, 2.73%, N, 12.63%; found C, 38.45%, H, 2.71%, N, 12.34%. Raman (cm–1): 3315 (w), 3078 (w), 2241 (m), 2227 (m), 1602 (m).

Elemental analysis for C15H12N4O3S1F3Ag1 (493.22): calcd C, 36.53%, H, 2.45%, N, 11.36%, S, 6.50%; found C, 36.48%, H, 2.51%, N, 11.26%, S, 6.24%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3479 (w), 3372 (m), 3214 (w), 2244 (w), 2215 (m), 1629 (m), 1602 (m), 1513 (m). Raman (cm–1): 3068 (w), 2241 (m), 1602 (m).
